about-me.title: Goal-Oriented Therapy
about-me.paragraph:
I focus on providing professional support to those facing various mental challenges, whether it's anxiety, depression, excessive stress, feeling overwhelmed, self-esteem issues, or relationship difficulties. In my work, I combine elements of cognitive-behavioral therapy, mindfulness, and schema therapy. I work under regular supervision.

My goal is to create a safe space where you can feel understood, prioritize yourself, and together we will find ways to help you start feeling better as soon as possible. Therapy is tailored to your individual needs, and we will work together to achieve lasting changes that lead to a more fulfilling and balanced life.
about-me.subtitle: A Few Words About Me
about-me.subparagraph: I am a psychologist, lecturer, and therapist, working at the National Institute of Mental Health. I host a podcast on relationships and continually expand my education – both through my doctoral studies in clinical psychology at Charles University and through various courses and activities in the field of mental health.

curriculum-vitae.title: Education and Qualifications
list: Holder of a Master's degree in Psychology from the University of Oxford
Currently pursuing a PhD in Clinical Psychology and Health Psychology at Charles University
Enrolled in a five-year therapeutic training in Cognitive Behavioral Therapy at the Odyssea Institute (Czechia)
Training in the STRONG programme (a programme supporting the adaptation of children and adolescents to a new environment)
Since 2022, working at the National Institute of Mental Health, focusing on the mental health of children and parents
Lecturer for the 'On my mind' programme within the National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH)
Training in cognitive-behavioral therapy led by a team from the University of Oxford to support parents of anxious children
Training to support the mental health of children, parents, and teachers in the Czech Republic affected by the war in Ukraine (UNICEF)
Training course for peer consultants at Durham University
Mentoring adolescents as part of the YODA mentorship programme

content.title: Mutual Trust
content.text: In our first meeting, I will introduce you to the therapeutic approach I work with, and you will share what you would like to get from therapy. Through a 30-minute conversation, we will decide together whether and on what issues we will work during the individual sessions.

content.title: Safe Environment
content.text: Meetings can be held online or at my therapy office in Vinohrady, Prague.

content.title: Terms of Cooperation
content.text: Payments can be made in cash or by bank transfer. The price for one session is 1200 CZK/50 EUR (50 minutes). Initially, I will schedule a free 30-minute online meeting with you, where we will decide if we will work together. Sessions can be canceled free of charge up to 48 hours before the appointment. If canceled less than 48 hours in advance, the full session fee must be paid.

card.title: Do you feel that therapy could help you?
card.text: Write to me, and I will be happy to arrange an online call to discuss whether and on what we will collaborate.

questions.question: What do the sessions look like?
questions.answer: Each session lasts 50 minutes. During the first three sessions, you will describe your situation to me in more detail. I will ask follow-up questions, and together we will set the goals for our collaboration. Each session is based on mutual conversation, asking open-ended questions, psycho-education on relevant topics, moments for reflection, and the use of specific methods. These elements help to shift the perspective on the situation and allow for a more flexible approach to the topic.

questions.question: How often will we meet?
questions.answer: Initially, we will meet once a week. After the initial phase of therapy, we will meet 1-2 times a month. Possible maintenance sessions can be held once every 2-3 months. It always depends on a mutual agreement with the client, and we can adjust the frequency of meetings according to your preferences.

questions.question: Do I need to bring anything?
questions.answer: Some clients like to take notes during therapy, so a notebook may be useful. Otherwise, you don't need to bring anything. I will offer you water or tea in the therapy room.

questions.question: When should I arrive?
questions.answer: Please arrive right on time, as I do not have a waiting room in my therapy space.

questions.question: Can we meet online? And how does it work?
questions.answer: Meeting online is perfectly fine, and some clients prefer this option due to time constraints (ot their location). We will meet on Zoom, I will send you a link before the session.

questions.question: How will I pay?
questions.answer: You can pay either in cash on-site or by bank transfer (always within 24 hours after the session).

list.name: Caroline
list.text: Since I had been struggling with anxiety for a long time, feeling constantly stressed and sensing that I needed a helping hand, I contacted the psychologist Marie Polášková about a year ago. From the very beginning, she offered me intensive therapy, specifically Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT), which is the best form of therapy for me. During the first few sessions, I was unsure about the therapy, as it is very difficult for me to open up to someone, but over time, I built trust with her, and we started the therapy in full swing! Gradually, we began to uncover potential causes of my stress and anxiety and started working on them together. Mrs. Polášková is the first person who has helped me start working on my anxiety because she always explains everything clearly, and I leave each session with new insights and another method or tool to help me reduce my anxiety and stress so they don't limit me as much in life. She won me over with her character and calm demeanor; I feel tranquility and ease from her because she always has a smile on her face and is always there to offer a helping hand. She is also a very empathetic person who sympathizes with you and always understands the problems you bring to her. Not to mention, she showed me there is nothing to be ashamed of if you start to cry during therapy. I am happy to continue with the therapy because I see certain progress in myself in managing my emotions and anxiety, and for that, I am very grateful to her and thank her so much!

list.name: Jessie
list.text: Therapeutic sessions with Marie allowed me to reflect on various changes and challenges happening in my life. She created a calm and friendly atmosphere where I could share even vulnerable things. Our sessions brought positive changes and growth in my personal life.

list.name: L.
list.text: I was glad to have found a therapist like Marie, as the sessions with her helped me a lot and gave me different tools to manage my problems. One of the main factors that helped me in the therapy process was the pleasant atmosphere and open communication that Marie was able to create. It helped me be open not only with the therapist but also with myself.

content.title: Data ukazují, že se čeští žáci a studenti necítí dobře. Dnešní děti se rodí do velmi nejisté doby, díky internetu jsou neuvěřitelně informovaní, mají přístup ke zprávám z celého světa a bojí se věcí jako tornádo nebo válka, které nikdy nezažily. Psycholožka Marie Polášková v oboru získala magisterský titul na Oxfordu a své poznatky se teď snaží přenést do Česka. Například v rámci projektu Bez obav, který pomáhá rodičům s úzkostnými dětmi. „Žádný strach by neměli brát na lehkou váhu. Zároveň si dítě musí zažít, že má před sebou těžké věci, rodič by mu měl umožnit překážky překonat,“ dodává.

Víme, že polovina všech duševních obtíží se projevuje před 14. rokem života a že je nedostatek dětských psychologů a psychiatrů. Na to je třeba reagovat, proto jsme vytvořili tento intervenční program pro rodiče. Namísto toho, aby dítě chodilo k psychologovi, se rodič účastní s ostatními rodiči kurzu, kde se školí v tom, jak své dítě podpořit a získává nejrůznější techniky a nástroje, zkouší si tam rozhovor s ostatními rodiči, který pak může praktikovat doma a pak ty techniky s dítětem využívá a pomáhá mu.“ O tom, jakým způsobem může projekt Bez obav pomoci v obtížných situacích promluvila ve Studiu 6 na Česká televize výzkumnice Marie Polášková.

Podcast o vztazích, který se zaměřuje na příběhy reálných lidí. Dvě psycholožky mají za cíl normalizovat, že jsou v partnerských vztazích horší i lepší chvíle a je v pořádku, že někdy se nám je podaří překonat a někdy ne.

Na nedostatek odborné péče v oblasti duševního zdraví dětí se psycholožky Marie Polášková a Marta Fišerová z Národního ústavu duševního zdraví (NUDZ) rozhodly zareagovat včasnou prevencí. Jejich vzdělávací program „Bez obav“ je určený pro rodiče, jejichž děti trpí úzkostmi. „Rodič se zapojí do skupiny a stává se průvodcem i pomocníkem dítěte na cestě při překonávání obav,“ popisují autorky projektu.
Když tě trápí úzkost, odložíme ji do krabičky. I to se učí rodiče v novém kurzu, vysvětlují psycholožky

O duševní zdraví se učíme zodpovědně pečovat až v posledních letech, zvláště u dětí a dospívajících to donedávna nebylo „téma“. Dnešní mladá generace sice žije zdánlivě v komfortu, ale i ona se potýká s řadou problémů. Jedním z nich je prakticky neomezené spektrum možností a tlak na neustálé rozhodování. Třeba o tom, jaké školy studovat, a to nejen v Česku, ale i v zahraničí. S tím chce studentům pomoci EduFestival, kde vystoupí i Marie Polášková. Sama vystudovala univerzity v Anglii a duševnímu zdraví dospívajících se věnuje nyní i v Česku.

Úzkosti jsou částečně dědičné. Rodiče učíme, aby se nebáli dát strach najevo, ale nepřenášeli ho dál: „Na odbornou pomoc čekáme v Česku půl až třičtvrtě roku. Zaměřme se tedy na to, co můžou udělat rodiče,“ říkají Matěj Kučera a Marie Polášková z Národního ústavu duševního zdraví.

Krabicové dýchání, metoda 5-4-3-2-1. Jaké techniky pomáhají dětem zvládnout strach, úzkost a paniku? „Často je to škola, strach o rodiče, separační úzkost, strach ze tmy. Děti můžou silně plakat, mělce dýchají, buší jim srdce. Snažíme se jim zklidnit dech pomocí krabicového dýchání, dýchání do jedničky nebo jejich pozornost odvedeme jinam metodou 5-4-3-2-1,“ popisuje Marie Polášková, psycholožka z Národního ústavu duševního zdraví.
